1010.desc: The BLOSUM matrices were introduced by Henikoff and Henikoff in1992. The BLOSUM-40 matrix  is derived from amino acid pair frequencies in alignment blocks of protein sequence databases and is widely used for sequence alignment and comparison.  Cannata et al. used BLOSUM-40 to calculate the amino acid reduction alphabets.
1010.vancouver: Cannata N, Toppo S, Romualdi C, Valle G. Simplifying amino acid alphabets by means of a  branch and bound algorithm and substitution matrices [Internet]. Vol. 18, Bioinformatics. Oxford University Press (OUP); 2002. p. 1102-8. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/18.8.1102

1000.desc: Schemes for reducing amino acid alphabet based on the BLOSUM50 matrix by Henikoff and Henikoff derived by grouping and averaging the similarity matrix elements as described in the text. The most correlated amino acids naturally form groups which have similar physiochemical properties.

1116.desc: The BLOSUM50 matrix was deduced from amino acid pair frequencies in alignedblocks of a protein sequence database and was used to generate reduced amino acid alphabets. From the way that the pair frequency counts are obtained, the BLOSUM50 data are more related to the evolutional difference of residues.
1116.vancouver: Liu X, Liu D, Qi J, Zheng WM. Simplified amino acid alphabets based on deviation of conditional probability from random background [Internet]. Vol. 66, Physical Review E. American Physical Society (APS); 2002. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.66.021906

1129.vancouver: Liu X, Liu D, Qi J, Zheng WM. Simplified amino acid alphabets based on deviation of conditional probability from random background [Internet]. Vol. 66, Physical Review E. American Physical Society (APS); 2002. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.66.021906

1181.desc: Reduced alphabets based on the BLOSUM50 substitution matrix and the charged were used to decrease the number of vectors needed to represent protein sequences. There are three categories according to charge. K and R are Positive. A, N, C, Q, G, H, I, L, M, F, P, S, T, W, Y, and V are Neutral. D and E are Negative.
1181.vancouver: Weathers EA, Paulaitis ME, Woolf TB, Hoh JH. Reduced amino acid alphabet is sufficient to accurately recognize intrinsically disordered protein [Internet]. Vol. 576, FEBS Letters. Wiley; 2004. p. 348-52. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.febslet.2004.09.036

1182.desc: Reduced alphabets based on the BLOSUM50 substitution matrix and the chemical properties of hydrophobic were used to decrease the number of vectors needed to represent protein sequences. F, I, L, V, W and Y are the strong hydrophobic amino acids. A, C, G, M and P are the weak hydrophobic amino acids. D, E, H, N and R are the strong hydrophily amino acids. K, Q, S and T are the weak hydrophily amino acids.
1182.vancouver: Weathers EA, Paulaitis ME, Woolf TB, Hoh JH. Reduced amino acid alphabet is sufficient to accurately recognize intrinsically disordered protein [Internet]. Vol. 576, FEBS Letters. Wiley; 2004. p. 348-52. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.febslet.2004.09.036

1183.desc: Reduced alphabets based on the BLOSUM50 substitution matrix and polar were used to decrease the number of vectors needed to represent protein sequences. L and V are the non-polar amino acids.

1378.desc: In this work, Li et al. used BLOSUM62 as a starting point to simplify the amino acid alphabet, and used a heuristic Monte Carlo (MC) method to approximate the optimal solution. Residues with similar physicochemical properties were often grouped together, as expected. In addition, the similarity is scored by a similarity matrix, which may help to identify protein folds.
1378.vancouver: Li T, Fan K, Wang J, Wang W. Reduction of protein sequence complexity by residue grouping [Internet]. Vol. 16, Protein Engineering Design and Selection. Oxford University Press (OUP); 2003. p. 323-30. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/protein/gzg044

1438.desc: In this work, Tanping et al. integrated the information on compositions of residues into the reduction of the residue alphabet, and cluster similar amino acids into groups using a global alignment method. The representative residues for each group are also obtained. Their alphabet mainly preserves the maximum information of the original protein sequence. Amino acids were clustered according to the maximum fraction of different reduction levels.

1512.desc: Wang et al. Clustering of amino acids based on their  physicochemical properties. There are three categories according to charge. K and R are Positive. A, N, C, Q, G, H, I, L, M, F, P, S, T, W, Y, and V are Neutral. D and E are Negative.
1512.vancouver: Wang J, Yang B, Leier A, Marquez-Lago TT, Hayashida M, Rocker A, et al. Bastion6: a bioinformatics approach for accurate prediction of type VI secreted effectors [Internet]. Hancock J, editor. Vol. 34, Bioinformatics. Oxford University Press (OUP); 2018. p. 2546-55. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/bty155

1676.desc: Electric charge is a physical property of matter. The first cluster includes negatively charged amino acids with E and D. The second cluster contains uncharged amino acids with A, N, C, Q, G, I, L, M, F, P, S, T, W, Y, and V. The last cluster is composed of positively charged amino acids H, K, and R. Generally, neutral uncharged amino acid PI=5.0~6.5, negatively charged amino acid PI≈3.0, positively charged amino acid PI=7.58~10.8.

1610.desc: Melissa A Ilardo and Stephen J Freeland run the 20 amino acids of the standard genetic code in terms of amino acid charge (pI), size (ACD molar volume), and hydrophobicity (ACD LogP) on a simple 3-dimensional chemical space. They show that the genetic code may start with only half of the 20 amino acids found in the current standard genetic code.
1610.vancouver: Ilardo MA, Freeland SJ. Testing for adaptive signatures of amino acid alphabet evolution using chemistry space [Internet]. Vol. 5, Journal of Systems Chemistry. Springer Science and Business Media LLC; 2014. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1186/1759-2208-5-1

1423.desc: Amino acids are clustered based on contact potentia. In each case, the alphabet size was chosen according to that deemed best by the source study in question. Within each simplified alphabet, amino acid groupings are comma delimited. Branch score distances indicate the effect of dropping each study on the overall consensus tree.
1423.vancouver: Stephenson JD, Freeland SJ. Unearthing the Root of Amino Acid Similarity [Internet]. Vol. 77, Journal of Molecular Evolution. Springer Science and Business Media LLC; 2013. p. 159-69. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00239-013-9565-0

1359.desc: The clustering of residues using dynamic clustering method for the sequence subset from the DAPS database. When residues are clustered into some groups, the coordinate center of each group and the distance of every residue to the center can be calculated. The main idea of the dynamic clustering method is to obtain the minimized value of the summation of these distances by dynamic programming algorithm.

1456.desc: This method is a computer algorithm jointly developed by R-F-Smith and T-F Smith, which extracts the patterns of conserved main sequence elements shared by all members of the homologous protein family. 1686.desc: Essential amino acids refer to amino acids that cannot be synthesized by the human body or whose synthesis rate cannot meet the needs of the human body and must be ingested from food. Nine essential amino acids for young children are KWFMTILVH, ACDEGNPQRSY are non-essential amino acid for young children.

1589.desc: This method uses Euclidean distance. Each amino acid is represented by a vector of numerical measurements for properties such as volume, area, hydrophilicity, polarity, hydrogen bonding, shape, and charge. The inter-residual distances are then calculated based on a common metric, and a new clustering objective function derived from information-theoretic considerations is introduced. Similar amino acids are grouped together.
1589.vancouver: Stanfel LE. A New Approach to Clustering the Amino Acid [Internet]. Vol. 183, Journal of Theoretical Biology. Elsevier BV; 1996. p. 195-205. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1006/jtbi.1996.0213

1246.desc: ECGA is used to find the optimal alphabetreduction of the predetermined size using the objective function that is based on dual robust mutual information for the solvent accessibility feature. This strategy shows that the target AA and its environment (the window composed of the nearest neighbours of the target in the protein chain) might benefit from two different reductions. Thus, one reduction policy was used specifically for the target residue and another reduction policy was used for the other residues in the window.

1272.desc: Susko et al. investigate the use of Markov models of evolution for reduced amino acid alphabets or bins of amino acids. The use of reduced amino acid alphabets can ameliorate effects of model misspecification and saturation. The bins were constructed based on hierarchicalclustering of the Grantham distance matrix and this distance matrix is based on the chemical properties of the amino acids alone and not rates of exchange between them.
1272.vancouver: Susko E, Roger AJ. On Reduced Amino Acid Alphabets for Phylogenetic Inference [Internet]. Vol. 24, Molecular Biology and Evolution. Oxford University Press (OUP); 2007. p. 2139-50. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/molbev/msm144

1153.desc: Hierarchical clustering of amino acids found that Glycine and Proline, which associated to specific local conformations of the protein backbone orientation, exhibited high specificities and could not be associated with other amino acids. The remaining 18 amino acids were grouped into three clusters. The first cluster, mainly hydrophobic, is composed of : I, V, F, Y, and W. The second cluster is more heterogeneous in terms of physico-chemical properties. It is composed of sub-clusters A, L, M, E, Q, R, and K. The last cluster includes polar amino acid with N, D, H, S, T, and C.
1153.vancouver: Etchebest C, Benros C, Bornot A, Camproux AC, de Brevern AG. A reduced amino acid alphabet for understanding and designing protein adaptation to mutation [Internet]. Vol. 36, European Biophysics Journal. Springer Science and Business Media LLC; 2007. p. 1059-69. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00249-007-10188-5

1154.desc: Hierarchical clustering of amino acids found that Glycine and Proline, which associated to specific local conformations of the protein backbone orientation, exhibited high specificities and could not be associated with other amino acids. The remaining 18 amino acids were grouped into three clusters. The first cluster, mainly hydrophobic, is composed of the sub-clusters: I, V (aliphatic amino acids) and F, Y, W (aromatic). The second cluster is more heterogeneous in terms of physico-chemical properties. It is composed of sub-clusters A, L, M (hydrophobic) and E, Q, R, K (polar/charged long amino acids). The last cluster includes polar amino acid with the sub-cluster N and D (polar/charged short amino acids) and the sub-cluster H, S, T and C (short and polar amino acids).
1154.vancouver: Etchebest C, Benros C, Bornot A, Camproux AC, de Brevern AG. A reduced amino acid alphabet for understanding and designing protein adaptation to mutation [Internet]. Vol. 36, European Biophysics Journal. Springer Science and Business Media LLC; 2007. p. 1059-69. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00249-007-10188-5

1155.desc: Hierarchical clustering of amino acids found that Glycine and Proline, which associated to specific local conformations of the protein backbone orientation, exhibited high specificities and could not be associated with other amino acids. The remaining 18 amino acids were grouped into three clusters. The first cluster, mainly hydrophobic, is composed of the sub-clusters: I, V (aliphatic amino acids) and F, Y, W (aromatic). The second cluster is more heterogeneous in terms of physico-chemical properties. It is composed of sub-clusters A, L, M (hydrophobic) and E, Q, R, K (polar/charged long amino acids). The last cluster includes polar amino acid with the sub-cluster N and D (polar/charged short amino acids) and the sub-cluster H, S, T, and C (short and polar amino acids). Then the sub-cluster H, S, T and C can grouped by H, S and T, C.

The second cluster is more heterogeneous in terms of physico-chemical properties. It is composed of sub-clusters A, L, M (hydrophobic) and E, Q, R, K (polar/charged long amino acids). 1290.desc: The tree-like distribution of residues using hierarchical clustering method directly based on substitution scores for sequence subset from DAPS database with sequence identities S≦30%. And the distance between groupings in tree describes the information loss of two groupings in information theory. All 20 letters are clustered into the hydrophobic and polar divisions naturally at different levels.
1290.vancouver: Li J, Wang W. Grouping of amino acids and recognition of protein structurally conserved regions by reduced alphabets of amino acids [Internet]. 1611.desc: L Adamian, J Liang, et al. Hierarchical clustering grouping of 20 amino acid residues by correlation coefficients of pairwise values of membrane helical interfaces. Settlement calculators with common tendencies are grouped together. This clustering method answers how the voids and pockets in the TM region are distributed, what is the coordination number of the residues in the TM region, what are the specific inter-helix interactions, and whether there is a way of packaging between helical membrane proteins and helical soluble proteins different issues.

1630.vancouver: Li X, Hu C, Liang J. Simplicial edge representation of protein structures and alpha contact potential with confidence measure [Internet]. Vol. 53, Proteins: Structure, Function, and Bioinformatics. Wiley; 2003. p. 792-805. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/prot.10442

1515.desc: Yu et al. propose a new chaos game representation (CGR) based on the protein sequence of a detailed HP model. Correlation distances of differences between protein sequence CGR-based measures and their fractal backgrounds are also proposed to construct more precise bacterial phylogenetic trees.In this HP model amino acids can be divided into four classes: nonpolar,  uncharged polarity, positive polarity, and negative polarity.The eight residues A; I; L; M; F; P; W and V designate the non-polar class; the seven residues N; C; Q; G; S; T and Y designate the uncharged polar class; the remaining three residues R; H and K designate the positive polar class, and the two residues D and E designate the negative polar class.
1515.vancouver: Yu ZG, Anh V, Lau KS. Chaos game representation of protein sequences based on the detailed HP model and their multifractal and correlation analyses [Internet]. Vol. 226, Journal of Theoretical Biology. Elsevier BV; 2004. p. 341-8. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jtbi.2003.09.009

1508.desc: Wang et al.  Clustering of amino acids based on their sequence information, evolutionary information and physicochemical properties. There are three categories here based on hydrophobicity. R, K, E, D, Q, and N are Polar, G, A, S, T, P, H and Y are Neutral, and C, L, V, I, M, F and W are Hydrophobicity.
1508.vancouver: Wang J, Yang B, Leier A, Marquez-Lago TT, Hayashida M, Rocker A, et al. Bastion6: a bioinformatics approach for accurate prediction of type VI secreted effectors [Internet]. Hancock J, editor. Vol. 34, Bioinformatics. Oxford University Press (OUP); 2018. p. 2546-55. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/bty155

1674.desc: The method takes into account the hydrophilic and hydrophobic properties of each of the 20 amino acid side chains. Arranged in descending order of hydrophilicity, that is, R has the strongest hydrophilicity, and I has the strongest hydrophobicity. This method plays an important role in studying the structure of proteins.
1674.vancouver: Kyte J, Doolittle RF. A simple method for displaying the hydropathic character of a protein [Internet]. Vol. 157, Journal of Molecular Biology. Elsevier BV; 1982. p. 105-32. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0022-2836(82)90515-0

1681.desc: Both serine (S) and threonine (T) have hydroxyl groups on their side chains. Serine is a neutral aliphatic hydroxyl-containing amino acid and a non-essential amino acid. Its chemical formula is C3H7NO3, its molecular weight is 105.09, and its melting point is 496-501 K. It is easily soluble in water and almost insoluble in non-polar solvents. Threonine was discovered in fibrin hydrolyzate in 1935 by W.C.Ro and proved that it is the last essential amino acid to be discovered. Its chemical name is a-amino-b-hydroxybutyric acid, and there are four stereoisomers, and only the L-type has biological activity.

1254.desc: Susko et al. investigate the use of Markov models of evolution for reduced amino acid alphabets or bins of amino acids. The use of reduced amino acid alphabets can ameliorate effects of model misspecification and saturation.The saturation bins(amino acid clusters) were constructed from the JTT rate matrix and  the criterion used to choose bins is to maximize theratio of the expected number of substitutions within bins to the expected number under the Jukes-Cantor model.
1254.vancouver: Susko E, Roger AJ. On Reduced Amino Acid Alphabets for Phylogenetic Inference [Internet]. Vol. 24, Molecular Biology and Evolution. Oxford University Press (OUP); 2007. p. 2139-50. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/molbev/msm144

1437.desc: Daniel et al. proposed a DNN model for AMP classification, and it's successful method to apply the DNN to learn basic amino acid physicochemical properties. They considerd deep learning due to its ability to identify multiple, ambiguous patterns possibly hiding within the diverse families of AMP peptides represented in their comprehensive data set.
1437.vancouver: Veltri D, Kamath U, Shehu A. Deep learning improves antimicrobial peptide recognition [Internet]. Hancock J, editor. Vol. 34, Bioinformatics. Oxford University Press (OUP); 2018. p. 2740-7. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/bty179

1250.desc: Wang et al. present a reduction method based on an analysis of the statistical contact potentials of the MJ matrix. These sequences are well optimized for a certain compact structure taken as the native one at a low opti mization temperature T = 0.8 by annealing in the sequence space using the MJ matrix as the energy matrix. The results suggest that by considering hydrophobicity, the N = 5 group reduction may work well. Furthermore, the differences between polar residues seem to be more important than that between hydrophobic ones within a grouping.
1250.vancouver: Wang W, Wang J. Vol. 6, Nature Structural Biology. Springer Science and Business Media LLC; 1999. p. 1033-8. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/14918

1101.desc: Liu et al. improved the Miyazawa Jernigan (MJ) matrix which was derived from the frequencies of contacts between different amino acid residues in a set of known native protein structure databases, and they generated the schemes for amino acid alphabet reduction.  And a strong correlation between classification based on MJ matrix and hydrophobic values of amino acids were found by them.

1677.desc: According to the polarity of the R group or the propensity to interact with water at physiological pH (near pH 7.0), it can be divided into non-polar amino acids (A, C, G, I, L, M, F, P, W, and V) and polar amino acids (R, N, D, Q, E, H, K, S, T, and Y). Polar amino acids usually have a certain affinity for water molecules and can generally form hydrogen bonds with water molecules. Non-polar amino acids generally have low or very low affinity for water molecules, but higher affinity for fat-soluble substances.

1680.desc: Methionine (M) and cysteine (C) are a class of amino acids that contain sulfur atoms in their molecules. The others are amino acids that do not contain sulfur. Methionine has no optical activity. Methionine is heat and air stable. Methionine is easily soluble in water (3.3g/100ml, 25℃, dilute acid and alkali, very slightly soluble in 95% ethanol, very insoluble in absolute ethanol, almost insoluble in ether. Cysteine, in the presence of sodium nitroprusside It is purple, molecular weight is 121.16. Cysteine, soluble in water, ethanol, acetic acid and ammonia, insoluble in ether.

1516.desc: The method is based on covariant patterns of five multidimensional properties of polarity, secondary structure, molecular bulk, codon diversity and electrostatic charge. The arithmetic mean cluster analysis was performed on the distances calculated from the scores for factor I using the unweighted pair method. Factor I is bipolar (large positive and negative factor coefficients) and reflects simultaneous covariation of exposed residual components. Provides a method to quantify the letter information inherent in biological sequences. Can help understand the evolutionary, structural and functional aspects of protein variation.
1516.vancouver: Atchley WR, Zhao J, Fernandes AD, Drüke T. Solving the protein sequence metric problem [Internet]. Vol. 102, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. 1532.desc: The method is based on covariant patterns of five multidimensional properties of polarity, secondary structure, molecular bulk, codon diversity and electrostatic charge. The arithmetic mean cluster analysis was performed on the distances calculated from the scores for factor II using the unweighted pair method. Factor II is a secondary structure factor. There is an inverse relationship of relative propensity for various amino acids in various secondary structural configurations, such as a coil, a turn, or a bend versus the frequency in a-helix.

1550.desc: The method is based on covariant patterns of five multidimensional properties of polarity, secondary structure, molecular bulk, codon diversity and electrostatic charge. The arithmetic mean cluster analysis was performed on the distances calculated from the scores for factor III using the unweighted pair method. Factor III relates to molecular size or volume with high factor coefficients for bulkiness, residue volume, average volume of a buried residue, side chain volume, and molecular weight. A large negative factor coefficient occurs for normalized frequency of a left-handed a-helix.

1552.desc: The method is based on covariant patterns of five multidimensional properties of polarity, secondary structure, molecular bulk, codon diversity and electrostatic charge. The arithmetic mean cluster analysis was performed on the distances calculated from the scores for factor III using the unweighted pair method. Factor III relates to molecular size or volume with high factor coefficients for bulkiness, residue volume, average volume of a buried residue, side chain volume, and molecular weight. A large negative factor coefficient occurs for normalized frequency of a left-handed a-helix.

The arithmetic mean cluster analysis was performed on the distances calculated from the scores for factor IV using the unweighted pair method. These attributes vary inversely with refractivity and heat capacity.

1343.desc: The distribution of residues using the UPGMA clustering method for sequence subset from the DAPS database and the clustering is based on BLOSUM30 matrix using the program of KITSCH in PHYLIP. In such an approach, every residue is mapped as a vector in a 20-dimensional space, and among them, two residues or two vectors with the shortest Euclidean distance are clustered into one group step by step.
1343.vancouver: Li J, Wang W. Grouping of amino acids and recognition of protein structurally conserved regions by reduced alphabets of amino acids [Internet]. Vol. 50, Science in China Series C: Life Sciences. Springer Science and Business Media LLC; 2007. p. 392-402. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s11427-007-0023-3

1682.desc: The method is derived from Lukasz P. Kozlowski's Proteome-pI: proteome isoelectric point database. Proteome-pI facilitates statistical comparisons of the various prediction methods as well as biological investigation of protein isoelectric point space in all kingdoms of life.
1682.vancouver: Kozlowski LP. Proteome-pI: proteome isoelectric point database [Internet]. Vol. 45, Nucleic Acids Research. Oxford University Press (OUP); 2016. p. D1112-6. Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/nar/gkw978

1684.desc: Acidic amino acids have less amino than carboxyl groups. Usually contains one amino group and two carboxyl groups, PI = 2.8 to 3.2. It is easily hydrolyzed in aqueous solution to release hydrogen ions and is negatively charged. DE two are acidic amino acids GYCAFHIKLMNPQRSTVW are non-acidic amino acids.

1678.desc: Fifteen amino acids of CDEFHKMNPQRSTYW are aliphatic amino acids. The five types of GAVLI are non-aliphatic amino acids, and aliphatic amino acids refer to amino acids directly composed of aliphatic hydrocarbon chains as R groups. Aliphatic amino acid surfactant is a kind of surfactant with low toxicity, low irritation and good biodegradability.

1685.desc: Alkaline amidic acid. Amino acids with more amino groups than carboxyl groups. Its characteristic is that the side chain often contains basic chemical groups that can be protonated, namely guanidine group, amino group and imidazole group.RKH are alkaline amidic acid, and CADEFGILMNPQSTVYW are non-alkaline amidic acid.

1683.desc: A distinction is made between amino acids that have an amide group in the R group of the side chain and an amino acid that does not have an amide group. Aspartic acid (D) and glutamic acid (Q) are amino acids containing an amide group. For mammals, aspartate is a non-essential amino acid because it can be made from oxaloacetate by transamination. For plants and microorganisms, aspartic acid is the source of several amino acids, including the four essential amino acids: methionine, threonine, isoleucine, and lysine. Glutamate has special physiological effects. Clinically, it is mainly used for hepatic encephalopathy caused by various reasons and some mental and nervous system diseases such as schizophrenia, small epilepsy, etc., and can also promote the intellectual development of children.

1679.desc: Four of FYWH belong to aromatic amino acids, the R group of the side chain is an aromatic compound, and the others are non-aromatic amino acids. Many plants and microorganisms can synthesize aromatic amino acids, and many herbicides can inhibit the synthesis of aromatic amino acids in weeds.
